NewsLines.HeadLine: Thousands of Palestinians back Arafat in protests

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MIDEAST-PROTESTS (PICTURE):Thousands of Palestinians back Arafat in protests

body.p: By Nidal al-Mughrabi

GAZA, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Carrying posters of Yasser Arafat and chanting his nom de guerre, thousands of Palestinians took to the streets of the West Bank and Gaza Strip on Monday to show solidarity with their besieged leader.

On the second day of demonstrations against the Israeli army siege of Arafat's headquarters in the West Bank city of Ramallah, protesters gathered in Gaza City, East Jerusalem and Bethlehem, Tulkarm and Qalqilya in the West Bank.

The protests underlined how the siege and the destruction of most of Arafat's compound -- launched after two suicide bombings and intended to isolate the Palestinian president -- have rallied public sympathy for him.

Carrying Palestinian flags and posters of Arafat, several thousand protesters, including women and children, marched through Gaza City to the ruins of Arafat's beachfront headquarters destroyed in a December air strike.
They shouted their willingness to "become martyrs" for the goal of Palestinian statehood as songs were broadcast on loudspeakers.
Many were supporters of Arafat's mainstream Fatah movement but others were armed activists from the militant al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades who fired from rifles into the air.
"We will burn the ground under the feet of the Israeli soldiers," the militants shouted.
In Bethlehem, a Reuters correspondent said a speech by Arafat, which he gave over the telephone, was broadcast on loudspeakers to about 2,000 students at Bethlehem University.
"What is happening now is a very dangerous act. The Palestinian people are struggling to defend their land and dream of establishing a state with Jerusalem as its capital," he said.
STONE-THROWING IN BETHLEHEM
Students later took to the streets of Bethlehem shouting: "Arafat is the symbol of peace, liberty and struggle."
About 200 students marched to Rachel's Tomb, a holy site revered by Jews and Muslims, and threw stones at soldiers there.
Israeli soldiers shot dead four protesters in the West Bank during the first day of protests on Sunday, but there was no word of any casualties in Monday's demonstrations.
Witnesses said several hundred protesters also marched through Tulkarm and Qalqilya. "We will sacrifice our blood and soul for Abu Ammar," they shouted in Qalqilya, using Arafat's nom de guerre.

Tayeb Abdel-Rahim, a top Arafat aide, said: "Our people is saying that its legitimate uprising and legitimate struggle will continue. We love to live but we are ready to die for the sake of a dignified and free life."
Palestinian officials and some Israelis say that although the siege has been humiliating for Arafat, it has also given him a reprieve from some of his political problems.

He is under pressure from the United States, Israel and the Palestinian parliament to carry out sweeping reforms and end government corruption, measures Washington says must come before talks resume on establishing a Palestinian state.
Israel hopes ordinary Palestinians will become disillusioned with the uprising they launched against Israeli occupation in September 2000.
But Israel's Maariv newspaper said: "The rebellion against Arafat which was gathering momentum over the past few weeks was suppressed and put down, at least temporarily, by Israel's bulldozers."
